Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Featuring EarthScope in Coastal Cascadia Earthquake and Tsunami Hazards Education by Linking Teachers, Interpreters, and Emergency Managers
Award.AbstractNarration:
The same geological forces that form the spectacular beaches and headlands of the Pacific Northwest also threaten our lives and infrastructure with earthquakes and tsunamis. This project, known as the Cascadia EarthScope, Earthquake, and Tsunami Education Program (CEETEP), helps to mitigate the effects of these potential disasters through collaboration building and professional development for K-12 teachers, park and museum interpreters, and emergency management outreach professionals in communities along the Oregon and Washington coast.

The March 11, 2011 great earthquake and tsunami that devastated Japan has heightened public concern about similar geologic hazards in our own country. As part of a nationwide effort, the NSF EarthScope Program has been deploying hundreds of seismic, GPS, and other geophysical instruments to measure movement of the Earth's crust and detect earthquakes along the Cascadia Subduction Zone. These instruments provide detail for ongoing research showing that coastal regions are storing energy that will be released in the next great Cascadia earthquake, with the resulting tsunami arriving onshore in 30 minutes or less. NSF and other organizations have compiled a list of Earth Science Literacy Principles that the educated public should know and appreciate (http://www.earthscienceliteracy.org). CEETEP, by drawing on EarthScope observations and results, especially helps to convey three of these concepts to students and the public: "Earth scientists use repeatable observations and testable ideas to understand and explain our planet;" "Earth is continuously changing;" and "Natural hazards pose risks to humans."

Tens of thousands of Oregon and Washington residents live within severe earthquake-shaking and tsunami-inundation zones, and millions of tourists visit state and federal parks in these same areas each year. Teachers in the K-12 school systems convey some basics about geological hazards to their students, and park rangers and museum educators likewise engage visitors at their sites. Both of these groups also at times work with emergency managers. CEETEP is strengthening these efforts by providing community-based workshops that bring together all of these professionals to review the basic science of earthquakes and tsunamis, learn about EarthScope and other research efforts that monitor the dynamic Earth in the region, and develop ways to collectively engage students and the general public on the mitigation of coastal geologic hazards.

The CEETEP effort involves geoscience educators from Oregon State University, Central Washington University, and the University of Portland. From 2013 to 2015, approximately eight workshops are being conducted in coastal communities of Oregon and Washington. Participating K-12 teachers and park interpreters are learning about ongoing research on Cascadia plate tectonics, earthquakes and tsunamis, and about how EarthScope is advancing frontiers of knowledge about geologic hazards in the region. Emergency management outreach leaders are also training the participants on emergency preparedness actions. Master teachers offer pedagogical guidance and ideas about assessment and interaction, while experienced interpreters discuss how to reach a variety of audiences in settings outside the classroom. This exchange of pedagogies among educators facilitates their collaboration and helps them communicate common messages about the science and mitigation of Cascadia geohazards. In follow-up share-a-thons, the teachers and interpreters showcase how they have crafted their new knowledge into Earth science and emergency preparedness learning experiences for K-12 students and visitors to parks and museums. This EarthScope educational program is critical to promoting a culture of geohazard awareness so America can prepare for and mitigate the effects of the next great Cascadia earthquake and tsunami, as well as smaller earthquakes and tsunami from distant sources.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Cascadia Earthquake and Tsunami Hazards Education Program (CEETEP; http://ceetep.oregonstate.edu/) aimed to improve Cascadia disaster resilience through educator professional development. Along the Cascadia coast, tens of thousands of residents live within tsunami-inundation zones and millions of tourists visit state and federal parks in these same high-risk areas each year. An original motivation for the EarthScope Program was that EarthScope science would “contribute to the mitigation of risks from geological hazards … and the public's understanding of the dynamic Earth.” The largest audience of geoscience learners in the U.S. is found in K-12 Earth science classrooms. Visitors to parks and museums who enjoy beautiful landscapes of special places are another vast audience of potential Earth science learners. These audiences must be reached to deliver on the promise to engage the public in EarthScope science.

CEETEP ran a series of six workshops and three follow-up Share-a-thons along the Cascadia coast in 2013-2016. Unlike most professional development programs, CEETEP targeted a spectrum of educators within each community, bringing together teachers, park/museum interpreters, and emergency management educators. We hypothesized that this model would promote exchange between different types of educators and lead to collaboration across coastal communities. This turned out to be strongly the case. The project goals were for participants to 1) learn and communicate geoscience (including EarthScope science), 2) understand and communicate risk, 3) take action and use the resources with a community and emergency managements system, and 4) exchange pedagogy and collaborate with colleagues. All of these help achieve the overall aim of improving Cascadia disaster resilience.

The workshops had some key characteristic. Two per year were held in the late summer and fall. They were four days each included two and a half days of science and preparedness content, a 1-day field trip, and half a day of action team planning. Content sessions were very interactive, mimicking the type of teaching that we hoped the participants would use with their own learners. Therefore presentations were regularly interspersed with hands-on activities and investigations with follow-up group discussion. In order to promote transfer to different learning venues, participants were given an extensive “educator kit” of demonstrations, investigations, maps, and digital resources. Presenters had a spectrum of expertise including geoscience, pedagogy, formal and informal teaching experience, and preparedness planning. Participants were divided into action teams of 3-7 people from a similar stretch of coast and including at least one each: teacher, park/museum interpreter, and emergency management educator. In the final day teams worked together to develop action plans of things they would do in the coming year. The Share-a-thon held the follow March each year brought participants from both previous workshops to report out on activities and discuss challenges and ways forward.

The CEETEP model was shown to be highly effective. Ninety-seven percent of participants “strongly agreed” that they would recommend the workshop to others. Participants took surveys before, immediately after, and six-months after each workshop. Overall survey results show that participants increased their science content knowledge, confidence in teaching earthquake and tsunami science and preparedness, optimism in the value of community-level preparedness actions to increase resilience, and personal preparedness actions. They also used a significant percentage of the teaching resources provided in the “educator kit” as well as accessing many online resources sites. They were very positive about the model of including a mixture of different types of educators together. Ninety percent agreed or strongly agreed that this was an effective model for professional development. Although they reported challenges in coordinating groups, many action teams or subsets of teams did continue to work together and implemented a wide range of school and community events to promote earthquake and tsunami learning in a variety of creative ways. These ranged from community events and schools and museums to art shows. One 5th grade classroom even did an analysis of local tsunami deposits and presented an attendant preparedness plan to their school administration based on their findings. In the six months following the workshops, participants estimated reaching more than 18,000 learners. They anticipated doubling this by the end of the first year. It is reasonable to assume that outreach continued and in subsequent years bringing the total of people reached to well over 50,000. Video footage from CEETEP workshops was also used to produce a 28-hour professional development online course for teachers from Washington and Oregon. The University of Portland offers the continuing education units free of charge. (http://ceetep.oregonstate.edu/sites/ceetep.oregonstate.edu/files/home/Cascadia-earthquake-online-teacher-pd-course.pdf)

In total the CEETEP program has met or exceeding all its goals and provides an excellent model for others to use in engaging educators in the science and preparedness of natural disaster reduction. A public validation of CEETEP’s achievements came when the project was awarded the Western States Seismic Policy Council’s “National Award of Excellence for Educational Outreach to Schools”
